awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Correlations and Entanglement: From CGC Wave Function to Particle Production at High Energy
awd_abstract_narration:
The strong force governs the interactions between protons and ions at very high energies. Complete understanding of strong interactions is a long standing problem in theoretical high energy and nuclear physics. For more than a decade, it has been known that under certain conditions these interactions can lead to very intricate collective behavior, like for example formation of a Quark-Gluon plasma. One of the central parts of the experimental program at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is the study of possible collective and correlated behavior in heavy ion collisions as well as proton-ion collisions at high energy. The latter are particularly interesting, since understanding collectivity may allow for progress in understanding the structure of the proton. As such, in this project the PI and his collaborators will study how collective behavior can originate in the properties of the wave function of the colliding objects. This project will provide excellent training of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

This project concerns the development of an approach based on the so-called Color Glass Condensate (CGC) - a modern approach to high energy interactions. The PI will study the possible connection between quasi collectivity and quantum properties of the hadronic wave function at high energy. The PI aims to improve the current knowledge of the CGC wave function at high energy. This involves resummation of large logarithmic corrections to current next-to-leading-order (NLO) calculations via a consistent use of the Born-Oppenheimer approach to a multiscale system, and extending the current calculations to denser projectiles via the WKB approximation. Furthermore, the PI will study the correlated behavior of particles produced from this state in a high energy collision, in particular effects of quantum entanglement of modes, as well as effects of quantum statistics and other properties of particle distributions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the period of the ward I have concentrated on three broad subjects.

The first one is the quesrion of unitarity of the high energy evolution. The issue here is the following. Currently the energy dependence of hadronic cross sections is studied with the help of the so called JIMWLK equation. Although the equation describes energy evolution of the scatteing amplitude, it can be viewed also as evolution of probabilities associated with the hadronic state. It turns out that when evolved with JIMWLK, these probabilites acquire unphysical properties, i.e. some become negative and some exceed unity. We have shown that this is related to the fact that JIMWLK evolution violates explicitly the symmetry between the projectile and target in the scattering. Clearly correct evolution must reserves unitarity in the form of positivity of probabilities. A necessary condition for that is to restore the projectile-target symmetry. We have solved this problem in a siple toy model in zero transverse dimensions. In this simple case we have proved that the unitarity is restored by a simple modification of JIMWLK evolution, and we have also shown that this modification changes the asymptotics of evoltuion consisten with our intuitive understanding of the high energy sauration phenomenon. We also studied the real QCD case and have suggested a similar modification of evolution. We were able to show that this modification restores the projectile-target symmetry, but the question of unitarity still remains open.

The second class of problems  I studied was the possible importance of quantum entanglement as a source of particle production in high energy collisions. I have probed a conjecture that the reduced density matrix of the observed degrees of freedom in high energy collisions is diagonal in the particle number basis, and therefore entanglement entropy directly translates into the Gibbs entropy of produced particles. By studying the CGC wave function and calcuating the reduced density matrix directly, I have shown that this is not in general the case. Although at high momentum all the entropy indeed originates from entanglement, at low momenta where saturation is important there is an order one difference between the entanglement and Gibbs entropies. Interestngly we also showed that the particle distribution gien by the reduced density matrix is very close to ideal Bose gas for particle momenta arond a semihard scale. This scale is detemined by the condition that occupation number is of order one, and is therefore parametrically higher than the saturation scale, but lower than the genuine hard scael wheere the occupation number is small.

The third class of problems is the possible experimental manifestations of saturation relevant for EIC. We have done a serious study of particle correlations in Ultraperipheral Collisions and found behavior of correlations that differs significantly frome earlieer studies, which treated hadronic structure in a very simplistic manner. In particular we fond that the second flow coefficient v2 flattens out at large transverse momenta, rathe than continues to rise as suggested by earlier work. We have also suggested an interesting observable to be studied at EIC - the correlation between a dijet and a thrid jet in diffractive configuration. We showed that this observables can detect Bose correlations between gluon in the hadronic wave function, and in addition it is ery sensitive to effects of saturaion whih effectively provides an infared cutoff on the allowed gluon momenta.
